sub_topic: Calculating the enthalpy and entropy of inorganic reactions
message_1: What is the change in entropy for the reaction 2H2(g) + O2(g) → 2H2O(g) at a temperature of 298 K?Given the standard entropy values of H2(g), O2(g), and H2O(g) are 130.6 J/K/mol, 205.0 J/K/mol, and 188.7 J/K/mol respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the change in entropy (ΔS) for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔS = ΣnS(products) - ΣnS(reactants)

where n is the stoichiometric coefficient and S is the standard entropy value for each species.

For the reaction 2H2(g) + O2(g) → 2H2O(g), the entropy change is:

ΔS = [2 × S(H2O)] - [2 × S(H2) + S(O2)]

Using the given standard entropy values:

ΔS = [2 × 188.7 J/K/mol] - [(2 × 130.6 J/K/mol) + 205.0 J/K/mol]

ΔS = [377.4 J/K/mol] - [466.2 J/K/mol]

ΔS = -88.8 J/K/mol

The change in entropy for the reaction is -88.8 J/K/mol.
